text:
486-494 Water Street, north side, between Pike Slip and Rutgers Slip. Nos. 486-488 is a frame shack and wall enclosing a lumber yard. (Direction of Water Street is arbitrarily set to run east
and west).
April 16, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
The same, and showing a further view eastward to and including Rutgers Slip. Note the absence of No. 492-494 a 6-story tenement shown
in No. 1.
March 21, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

text:
Water Street, north side, west from but not including Pike Slip. The view is taken from the Manhattan Bridge. The side of the building shown on the right is part of clearance from bridge construction and is not a street. The opposite side of the bridge
is Pike Slip. Breadline of mendicant's is shown.
June 8, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
The same, from a different angle.
July 9, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

title: Manhattan: Water Street - Pike Slip

text:

June 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Manhattan: Water Street - Pike Slip

text:
11 Peck Slip, north side, west of Water Street, showing an old structure that is supposed to have been standing in 1725, on land owned by Johans Hardenbrooke. It is now the property of Wm. H. Scheel. For further data see other views.

November 8, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Peck Slip - Water Street

text:
11 to 5 Peck Slip, north side, west of Water Street. No. 11 (right) is believed to have been standing in 1725 on land owned by Johans Hardenbrooke. This and other pieces of property on Peck Slip passed to the Roosevelt family in 1755, and from this unit passed to the Scheel family; the present owner being Wm. H. Scheel, importer of varnish gums. No. 9, the adjoining structure housed Ex-Governor Alfred E. Smith during his earlier days. North of the latter is a 3-story frame house, occupied by a junk shop, but formerly, the residence of Dr. Valentine of Valentines Manual fame.

October 1937.

George D. Chinn.
title: Manhattan: Peck Slip - Water Street

text:
Pike Slip, west side, north from, but not including Water Street, showing an anchorage of the Manhattan Bridge (left), at the N.W. corner of Cherry Street. The 6-story house and the 4-story stable adjoining it, (extreme left) the rears of which are shown, face on the south side of Monroe Street, and bear Nos. 75 and 78 respectively.

March 22, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Pike Slip - Water Street

text:
(1)
Pike Slip, east side, south from and including Water, to and including South Street. The Manhattan Bridge is shown overhead, extending out over the East River to Brooklyn.
June 17, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same from a slightly different angle.

April 25th, 1939

P. L. Sperr.

title: Manhattan: Pike Slip - Water Street

text:
Water Street, south across Peck Slip to Fulton Street. The towering 60 Wall Tower dominates the background and overshadows this, the Fulton Fish Market locale.

1939

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
title: Manhattan: Water Street - Peck Slip
